title: 115_hr2805
content: The Act titled "Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards Act of 2017" introduces business travel cards for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation region under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection can issue Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards (ABT Cards) to U.S. citizens in good standing with an international trusted traveler program, engaged in business in the Asia-Pacific region, or U.S. Government officials active in Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection can issue ABT Cards to U.S. citizens engaged in Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation business. Integration with existing travel programs and cooperation with private entities are allowed. A fee is prescribed for issuance and renewal of ABT Cards. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection can issue ABT Cards to U.S. citizens engaged in Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation business. A fee is charged for issuance and renewal of ABT Cards, adjusted as necessary to cover associated costs. Fees collected are deposited into an account to offset expenses. Fees collected for Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards are deposited to offset expenses. The funds are used for U.S. Customs and Border Protection expenses and remain available until expended. The Commissioner must notify relevant committees of any additional expenses incurred. Trusted Traveler Program is defined in this section. The term "trusted traveler program" is defined as a voluntary program that expedites clearance for pre-approved, low-risk travelers entering the United States. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. "Sec. 418. Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards." Amounts from the repealed Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards Act of 2011 are transferred to a new account under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. These funds can be used for expenses related to ABT Cards issued before or after the enactment date. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Card Account under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is closed after funds are transferred from the repealed Act of 2011. These funds can be used for expenses related to ABT Cards issued before or after the enactment date. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Card Account is closed and funds are transferred from the repealed Act of 2011. These funds can be used for expenses related to ABT Cards issued before or after the enactment date. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS AND REPEAL. Conforming Amendments to the Homeland Security Act of 2002 include the issuance of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Travel Cards Act of 2011 is repealed, but existing ABT Cards remain valid. Existing ABT Cards issued before the enactment of this Act will remain valid until their expiration date.
